Officially licensed by the NFL

28539.name: ShaNuCo
28539.description:
ShaNuCo, according to the game's rulebook, stands for Shapes, Numbers and Colors.

It is a card game with 76 very large playing cards (Approx. 3" x 4"). Of these, 64 are marked with all combinations of the numbers 1-4, each color of blue, red, purple and green, and either a circle, star, square or triangle.

The rest of the cards are either Wild, Super Wild, Pass or Show cards, in some combination of the three characteristics that the main cards represent.

It's box is approximately 4.5" x 6" x 1". Instructions are in English, French and Spanish, and fit on both sides of a 4" x 6" sheet of paper (per language).

2-4 Players.
The box claims 4-104 as appropriate ages for the game, but the rules are possibly too sophisticated for a child under 6 or 8 years of age.

The object of the game is to gain the most points after 5 rounds of play. Each player starts with 100 points, and each round a player may both gain or lose points, depending on game play.

Copyright 1996.
Published by International Playthings, Inc. (Parsippany, NJ, USA), it appears to be their product number P55001. Also credited on the box are Creative Concepts, Inc. and Excel Development Group, Inc. "Made in Canada"

28540.name: The Flintstones Mitt-Full Game
28540.description: Dexterity game that features mitts shaped to look like Fred, Wilma, Barney and Betty. The object of the game is to keep a ball balanced on the mitt without it rolling off as you try to do a series of moves determined by cards that you draw.

28541.name: Flying Thunder
28541.description:
The game is played on a 16-square foot playing mat with an electronic helicopter placed in the middle and controlled from a remote that runs under the mat. Players choose to be either Blue or Red (teams can be created if there are more than 2 players)and alternate turns. The object of the game is to collect bomb tokens totaling 6 or more points before the other player(or team).

The tokens are spread out on the mat with the point value face down and the player must pick up the tokens with the helicopter(the points become visible once picked up)and dropped onto the designated headquarters. There are also bomb and spy tokens that need to be dropped into the bomb bunker or the competing players headquarters, respectively.

That is the main play, there are also solo mission and time variations.

28542.name: Goomicus
28542.description:
Alphabet Soup Word Game. Object is to construct words and achieve the highest letter word score in a given period of time. The Goomicus is a free letter and can be used to represent any letter of the alphabet. Ages 6 and up

Contents: Instruction pamphlet; bowl; spoon; 130 letters (8 of which are Goomicus (wild))

28543.name: Einstein
28543.description:
A computer with electronic lights and sounds. You have to do what Einstein tells you to do. Similar to "Simon" and "Maniac".

Made by Castle Toy Company in 1979 for ages 6 to adult and one or more players. Requires four “C” batteries.

28544.name: Walt Disney's Mickey Mouse If I Were In Your Shoes Game
28544.description: Collect the most tokens by staying out of another player's shoes. Ages 8 and up

28545.name: Madagascar Card Game
28545.description:
From the manufacturer's site:

I have Alex the Lion! Who has Marty the Zebra? If you have the right cards and the right speed - you win! Kids will love playing with their favorite Madagascar characters as they race to respond in order to win the game. This game also helps children build letter recognition and strengthen their reading vocabulary by using picture clues. Housed in a sturdy travel-tin, this card game includes two decks for two different ways to play. Includes 24 animal cards with green borders and 24 animal/letter cards with blue borders.

Ages 4 and up.

28546.name: Bones
28546.description:
Made by Ponder Mason Games in 1986 for Ages 7 and up.

Bones is a high rolling, exciting and challenging dice game with a race to get bonus points. It may be played solitaire or as many players as one wishes.

COMPLETE contents include: 5 dice, score cards, roll em’ bones pencil, and the instructions.

OBJECT: Finish the game with the highest score. Fun and thrills till the very last roll.

28547.name: Slumber Party
28547.description:
The game of fun and laughs for girls. So much fun your friends won’t want to leave!

Made by Cadaco in 1990 for up to six girls Ages 8 and up.

OBJECT: Be the first player to get rid of all your rollers, by acting, drawing, answering questions, doing a silly stunt, whatever the game cards tell you to do.

Contents include: 30 plastic hair rollers, pencil, timer, 110 game cards, Dear Diary with notepad, and the instructions.

28548.name: Happy Landing
28548.description:
A geography game made by Whitman in 1962 for 2-4 players Ages 12 and up.

A help yourself educational game for home and school.

COMPLETE contents include: large world map, colored disks, question cards, smaller map, cardboard inserts, and the instructions.

OBJECT: To acquire the greatest number of points by identifying locations indicated on the cards.

28549.name: In Other Words...
28549.description:
"In Other Words...
is a fun-filled mix of recall, deduction, strategy and wit. Players advance around the board by solving paraphrased clues to well-known titles, common terms, and popular sayings."

This game bills itself as the "Original Game of Paraphrases".

In this game, players move around the board and solve puzzles in one of five categories
-Movies and Television
-Terms
-Quotes & Sayings
-Literature
-Cliches & Expressions
-Music

The puzzles are in the form of phrases that have to be translated into the actual saying on the card. For example, the movie "Away With the Breeze" is "Gone With the Wind", and the book "The Victor's Ring" is "The Winner's Circle".

28550.name: Lion Sleeps Tonight Electronic Game
28550.description: This game has 2 levels of play for children Ages 3 and up. For the littlest children, you move according to color on the die. Older children move by number. It's a race to make it through the jungle, but meanwhile a lion is sleeping to his favorite song. If he wakes up during a child's move, they must hide in a bush. The first to get through the jungle wins.

28551.name: Show & Tell Game
28551.description:
A storytelling game for 2 to 4 players ages Ages 3 - 8.

The game consists of a board, spinner, and grab bag full of little toys. On each turn, a player gets to pick a toy from the bag. When a player lands on a storytelling space, he must tell a story involving all of the toys he has collected and the picture on the space he landed on. The first player to tell two stories wins.

28552.description:
For 2 to 4 players Ages 3 - 8.

Use your magnetic fishing pole to collect fish and put them together to make a puzzle. Includes 4 fishing poles, and 16 fish in 4 different colors.
28552.name: One Fish Two Fish Red Fish Blue Fish Game

28553.name: Fictionary
28553.description:
Fictionary is as rich as the idea is basic, and each game is completely different.

It is played with a dictionary. Each player takes two sheets of paper. One will be used for definitions, and each player writes his name on top of it. The other will be used for guesses. One of the players takes the dictionary and looks for an obscure word that, he thinks, all other players ignore (i.e. eguzla, exarch or jabot). He spells the word and tells what kind of word (verb, name, adjective).

Each player must now imagine and write down a plausible and convincing definition for this word. The player with the dictionary writes the true definition. When all players have written their definition down, the player with the dictionary takes all sheets, shuffles them, numbers, and reads aloud all the definitions. If necessary, he may read those two or three times. Each player must then write on his guess sheet who, in his opinion, has written each definition.

When all players have written their definitions, the player with the dictionary unveils the truth and tells who wrote what. Each player scores:

2 points if he found out the dictionary
1 point for each other player he found out
1 point for each player who thought his definition was the dictionary's one
If no one guessed what the true definition was, the player with the dictionary scores as many points as there are players.




When all players have scored their points, the player with the dictionary gives it to the player on his left. Play goes on until each player has had the dictionary once or twice.

There are numerous variants at http://www.faidutti.com/index.php?Module=ludotheque&;id=58.

Fictionary is also described at Wikipedia.

28554.name: Word Roulette
28554.description:
Read the clue on the card, spin the wheel and the first person who calls out a correct answer starting with the letter spun keeps the card which is counted as one point.

Similar to another game I know but this has a very solid well made wooden spinner with all the letters of the alphabet on it.

28555.name: DarkeStorme
28555.description:
From Publisher:
The fantastical world of Valon in the Dark Age. The time of swords and decaying Empires when Wylde Magicke ruled. Monsters and mayhem fit for champions. A world consumed by war and plunder where you as a Hero lead your band on a quest for riches and fame. Will the fates shine on you?

DarkeStorme has an easily learned 2D6 based rules system that is scenario driven with a normal game lasting between one and two hours in play. The game book features full rules, no need for expansions, create and advance your characters and creatures using a full points and species generation system. Also a full magic system and all needed rules for Chariots, Artillery and Monsters. Generate scenarios, the terrain and even the weather!

28556.name: Pyramid
28556.description:
Pyramid is a memory game for children. 2 to 6 players explore a Pyramid by lifting two lids. Should the icons be the same as the icons on any of the cards the player is holding in his hand, he may discard the card in question. The first who get rid of their cards is the winner.

Contents:
1 board with windows
15 lids to cover the windows with
15 tokens with icons
42 playing cards

28557.name: Flip kick
28557.description: This dexterity football (soccer) game is played on a little wooden table (58 x 40 x 8 cm) where each player tries to roll the ball in the opponent's goal using good old flipper (just like in a pinball machine). The play field is curved and filled with little rubber "players" which bounce the ball around.

28558.name: Go Fetch It
28558.description:
Go Fetch it is an exciting race game which uses an audio tape for both a full explanation of the rules & continuous instructions and music throughout the game play. The game consists of a game board, four dogs and a cassette tape. The dogs are set up on the board, then the tape is played. The players follow the instructions on the tape, as in "Dog X! Move forward two squares!" or "All dogs on yellow squares move back one square!" etc.

There are also some large plastic bones which have to be hidden or searched in other rooms than the ones the game takes place in. While one player is out for that task, the others continue - so the player outside should hurry. This unique & exciting game can be played at many different levels of difficulty & has numerous permutations of game play. You can start the game anywhere through the one hour tape !

28559.name: Lace Wars
28559.description:
Subtitle: "Wargaming the period 1660-1720"

Three different scale rules with mostly common mechanics.

Scale/One Unit/One inch:
1. Skirmish/Company (80-150 men)/25yd
2. Tactical/Battalion (400-600 men)/50yd
3. Grand/Brigade (3-5 battalions)/100yd

In addition to the rules, the book contains cardstock Play sheets, color-printed period Flags , 2 army lists (War of Spanish Succession France and Britain) and 5 scenarios. Complexity is not high, Play sheets consists of just 3 pages for all three scales. Typical play area is 6' x 4'.

There are 4 scenario books published.
1: Wars of Glory [Louis XIV's War of Devolution, Dutch & Rhineland Wars]
2: Wars of Grand Alliance [War of G.A., War in Ireland, Tangiers Campaign and Monmouth Rebellion]
3: The Great Northern & Turkish Wars
4: Wars of the Spanish Succession
Each scenario book contains several army lists, more than a dozen scenarios and color Flags.

28560.name: 11 Kings
28560.description:
A civilization game for 6+ players. The game is intended to be played with big groups and generally lasts around 7 hours.

This game was intended to be both flexible and streamlined. It's a civilization game with a modular hex board, a small number of technologies and relatively simple rules. Diplomacy is an important aspect of the game.

28561.name: Star Fleet Cards
28561.description:
This is non-collectible card game of spaceship combat set in the Star Trek universe. It is heavily inspired by the hex-and-counter game Star Fleet Battles. It is limited to a duel between two ships.

Each player gets a unique deck of cards that represents actions that their type of ship can make. Each turn players play cards based on how much energy their ship can still produce. At the point in the game when one players ship can no longer produce energy and therefore not play cards, that ship is considered defeated/destroyed and is considered the loser.

28562.name: Mr. Detective
28562.description: Obviously inspired by Clue, the object of the game is to move from city to city (rather than from room to room) to discern the location of a hidden bomb within eight game-days. A decently produced game, one of several released in 1985 by obscure Kits Game Corporation.

28563.name: Habet, Hoc Habet!
28563.description:
From the back cover:

The bloodthirsty spectators of the gladiatorial arena would shout out "Habet, hoc habet!" whenever a gladiator fell in combat. Now you can recreate those violent contests with the latest miniature wargaming rules from Flagship Games. Habet, Hoc Habet! includes:


Rules for recreating gladiator combat, where the actions of the individual determine all!
A campaign system where you play the gladiators' owner, training them for their bloody task, and sending them to their fate on the sands of the arena!
All the weapons used by the gladiators of ancient times!
Chariot races!
Hours of enjoyment for you and your gaming buddies!


Habet, Hoc Habet! faithfully recreates the life of the gladiator and the gladiator's owner, the Lanista, as the later strives to make his fortune while the former does his best to stay alive!

Habet, Hoc Habet! is a great game for two players or a whole club. You can play out an entire campaign in the course of an evening, and no more than a single figure per person is needed!

Make a claim for glory. Play Habet, Hoc Habet!

BONUS FEATURE: Fantasy Gladiator Rules!

Home Page: http://www.flagshipgames.com/html/habet__hoc_habet_.html

28564.name: Racepoly
28564.description: In Racepoly: The Race of the Century, players first engage in an "authentic auction" for international-class race horses, then pit their horses against each other in a complex race involving money management and various pitfalls. One of several decently produced games issued in 1985 by obscure Kits Game Corporation.

boardgamehonor: 2007 Japan Boardgame Prize Best Childgame Nominee
2007 Spiel der Spiele Hit für Kinder Recommended
28565.description:
Story: An evil king has burned all fairy tale books. Only one is left, and its sheets have been shredded and scattered in an enchanted garden. Now the players must hurry and find the matching pieces, and leave the garden with them, before the king returns.

Play: At any time, three book tiles are visible, the others are hidden below garden tiles. The player in turn may move up to two garden tiles (or rows of tiles). If there are two matching fairy tale pages visible after this move, he can collect this tale. If he doesn't find a match, the king moves one step. In addition, the player can move his pawn to an adjacent garden tile, or out of the garden if at the gate (but in this case, he can't collect any more tales).

Goal: The players must find as many tales as possible (preferably all), and leave the garden. If the king finishes his track, and there are still players left in the garden, all players lose.
28565.name: Save the Treasure of Fairy Tales
boardgamepodcastepisode: Episode 32 – Selecta Spielzeug – Neuheiten Frühjahr 2007

28566.description:
Lucky Luke - A Game of the Wild West is a simple set collection game. There are ten different gangs of outlaws in the deck. Each turn, one outlaw card is turned face up. Each player chooses one of their sheriff cards, which are then revealed simultaneously. The player with the highest sheriff cards wins the outlaw card.

Collecting a complete gang gives a cash reward. The player with the most money wins. There are also five special cards in the outlaw deck: Lucky Luke and Jolly Jumper let the player draw outlaw cards from the deck. Ran Tan Plan causes some captured outlaws to escape.
28566.name: Lucky Luke: Villin lännen peli

28567.name: I Don't Know, What Do You Want To Play?
boardgamepodcastepisode: The Spiel #27 - Diceversary
28567.description:
Unique game whose components consist of a card for every game in your collection. This is the perfect game to play when no one is being decisive! You are guaranteed to have chosen a game by the end of play.

Everyone plays out their cards until a final play pile is established and the final choice is pulled at random.

Create your own deck using your collection at:
http://www.superpowernosissies.com/games/idkwdywtp/

28568.name: Caravan
28568.description:
A pick up and deliver game where players trade goods and put up buildings. The 'robber' works against them as they try and build the most buildings.

The gameboard consists of an imaginary map showing four continents that are each divided into multiple countries. Every country is seeded with a token that represents one of eight different types of trade-goods. Players may pick up these tokens as they move their own pawn from country to country around the gameboard, and then collect payment for delivering the goods to a country where there is demand. Players spend their earnings to achieve a progression of game-ending conditions.

28569.description:
Part of a series of "Yotta Know..." games on different topics, Yotta Know Birds is a game played on a six-by-six grid board on which players place cards depicting birds to be identified. The first player to identify seven birds wins the round. Rolling dice adds a randomizing element to gameplay, while a handicap system allows players of varying knowledge levels to play against each other.
The game uses a deck of 60 birds, all of which are found in North America.
Expanded by:

Yotta Know Mammals
Yotta Know Waterfowl
28569.name: Yotta Know Birds

28570.name: Sling Dingers
28570.description: This is a game of Indoor Lawn Darts. Using plastic pieces and plastic targets players try to softly lob the pieces into circular targets. Succeed and score a point. The game advertises that it could be played outdoors but the pieces are just not sturdy enough for the pounding that an outdoor game would inflict on them and the pieces are so light that outdoor winds would play havoc with the game. Certainly best played indoors.

28571.name: Think-Thunk
28571.description: Think Thunk is a strategy action game. Each player has a group of men who attempt to cross the board while trying to avoid shots taken by an opponent with a ball fired by spring action levers. There are blocking pins scattered on the playing field where you would try and place your pieces in order to protect them from the firing line.

28572.name: Fishy Business!
28572.description:
From the box:
"A fabulously funny game of tropical fish trading!
Mr Plankton runs a crazy shop called Fishy Business. You've got to help him sell his weird and wonderful tropical fish, in particular the Outer Mongolian Mackerel, the Fantastic Finnish Flounder, the Brazilian Balloon Bloater and the Poisonous Tiger Trout.
Don't forget your fishing net!"

The winner is the player to get rid of all their cards first. Game play shares similarities with Uno, in that players play one card at a time from their hands, which must match either the same species as the previous card, or the same number. In addition, there are a selection of special cards which cause an opponent to pick up more fish from the pool, or which can be used to change species.

28573.name: Philanthropist: The National Gallery, London
28573.description:
Philanthropist: The National Gallery, London is the second art history trivia game from Mecenes Inc., following the more general Philanthropist. As the title suggests, Philanthropist: The National Gallery, London focuses on the holdings of one of Britain's foremost art museums.

At the heart of the game are the 100 color reproductions of paintings from the museum. Players compete to give away all of their money by answering questions about these paintings. Questions are multiple choice, or players may opt to play an "Expert" card and answer without the multiple choice options for a greater reward. Correct answers allow players to draw a "Philanthropist" card, which indicates the amount of a donation and has other effects.

Philanthropist: The National Gallery, London offers several variations on the game mechanics of the original, allowing players more strategic options and lifting this game above many standard trivia games.

28574.description:
This board game was produced by Sfera after the license for producing the Polish version of Talisman was revoked after the publication of a Sfera original expansion for Magia i Miecz called Jaskinia or The Cave.

It is very much like Talisman except that the board is "inside-out" in that you start in the middle of the board in a valley and work you way up to the mountains around the outside of the board. Instead of the Crown of Command you must battle your way through the Fortress of the Beast which is situated on a bridge which spans the board. Game's world is a bit more darker than heroic Talisman.

The basic layout of cards etc is the same as in Talisman except that Strength is replaced with Might and Craft with Magic.

A version of the game was later made without license by Phantom, a Russian firm.

Sfera produced a second edition of the game, which changed the style of the cards, but kept the art. The board was recreated using photo art and new character art was used. Only the base game was produced.
28574.name: Magiczny Miecz

28575.description:
Sfera released a number of expansions for Magiczny Miecz, three of which were very similar to expansions for Talisman.

Labyrint Magow (Mage's Labyrinth) was similar to the Talisman Dungeon.

It added a board and new cards to encounter. It also added Alternative Endings to the game, much like Talisman's Adventure expansion.
28575.name: Magiczny Miecz: Labirynt Magów

28576.name: Magia i Miecz: Jaskinia
28576.description:
This expansion is the only professionally produced expansion NOT to be produced by Games Workshop (or licensees of Talisman.

Jaskinia or the Cave, adds a new board to the game along with a new deck of cards to encounter.

It is thought to be a very difficult expansion as many of the enemies within the Cave have very high scores for Might or Magic.

It seems that the production of this expansion brought about an end to relations between Sfera and Games Workshop, as the license was revoked shortly after this.

Sfera went on to produce a Talisman-esque game, Magiczny Miecz.

28577.description:
This expansion was actually produced BEFORE the game of Magiczny Miecz was made as it was originally an expansion made for the Polish version of Talisman, Magia I Miecz.

Jaskinia or the Cave, adds a new board to the game along with a new deck of cards to encounter.

It is thought to be a very difficult expansion as many of the enemies within the Cave have very high scores for Might or Magic.

It is playable without Magiczny Miecz, with special rules. The goal is to get the Magic Crystal.
28577.name: Magiczny Miecz: Jaskinia

28578.name: Magiczny Miecz: Magia
28578.description:
Sfera's last expansion for Magiczny Miecz.

This added a number a cards to various decks, much like the Dragons expansion did for Talisman.

28579.description:
An expansion based again on underground movement for Magiczny Miecz.

Krypta Upiorow (Crypt of Wraiths) brings a new board and cards to encounter, new professions (few "Knights of Gods").

This is very diffucult expansion, specially because of different type of exploring the board.

It is playable without Magiczny Miecz, with special rules.
28579.name: Magiczny Miecz: Krypta Upiorów

28580.description:
Another expansion for Magiczny Miecz based loosely on a Talisman theme.

Grod (Town) is very much like Talisman City.

It brings a new board and cards to encounter and few professions (Steward, Chieftain of Thieves, Duke's Envoy, Master Wizard).
28580.name: Magiczny Miecz: Gród

28581.description:
Pelotera is a very unique game.

Have two main components:

50x70 cm board
2 dice.




Each player represents a soccer team and participates in a soccer game with other player. Each time you roll the dice you will be able to get closer to make a goal, but in the way anything can happen.

For Ages 7 and up
28581.name: Pelotera

28582.name: Blockade Runner
28582.description:
Blockade Runner was inspired by an actual Yankee civil war game. The chance of the Runner getting into port is about the same as in 1864.

After the USA began the blockage, merchant ships became runners. The Rewards were worth the risk. Blockade Runners were leaving England hoping for a big payday.

Two, three or four people play this fast acting game.

For Ages 10 and up.

28583.name: MinenRäumer
28583.description:
Minenräumer or Mine Sweeper has been a classic computer game for years now. The game is addictive for anyone that starts to play. Mine Sweeper now is available as a boardgame, where two players challenge each other to defuse one another's mines.
Both players deploy their mines in secret. After deployment the players call out locations to get information about the number of mines that surround it, or to defuse a mine in that field.

28584.name: Geheime Mission
28584.description: Players are spies trying to steal secret plans by playing cards into either the town or one of the embassies. Cards have 3 different values depending on the location /function they're played.

28585.description: There is a colorful meadow with flowers. Bees fly from flower to flower to collect pollen. Dice is rolled to move the bees. Small children learn to distinguish the different colors.
28585.name: Bienchen summ herum

28586.description:
A campaign pack for 5th edition Warhammer, Tears of Isha introduces a linked series of scenarios featuring the High Elf and Dark Elf armies.

Extra rules and special characters are introduced in the campaign pack. Box contents consist of the campaign rulebook; 4 battle scrolls for each player; a roster pad and card buildings used in the scenarios.
28586.name: Warhammer Tears of Isha

28587.description:
A campaign pack for 5th edition Warhammer, Grudge of Drong introduces a linked series of scenarios featuring the High Elf and Dwarf armies. The scenarios are set during the lead up to the Great War between the elves and dwarves.

Extra rules and special characters are introduced in the campaign pack. Box contents consist of the campaign rulebook; 4 battle scrolls for each player; a roster pad and card buildings used in the scenarios.
28587.name: Warhammer: Grudge of Drong

28588.description:
A campaign pack for 5th edition Warhammer, Idol of Gork introduces a linked series of scenarios featuring the Orc & Goblin and Empire armies.

Extra rules and special characters are introduced in the campaign pack. Box contents consist of the campaign rulebook; 4 battle scrolls for each player; a roster pad and card buildings used in the scenarios.
28588.name: Warhammer Idol of Gork

28589.name: Galactic Attack
28589.description:
Bagged game. From the bag cover:
"You are the Commander of the United States Space Forces Galactic Fleet. Recent intelligence reports state that the enemy have deployed an armada in a nearby solar system. Your mission is to push back the advancing fleets and repel the enemy forces."

A low-complexity game of ship-to-ship combat and planet occupation between identical forces approaching each other from opposite ends of a map representing a star system. The map has a square grid superimposed, and movement is orthogonal. On a turn, a player rolls two dice and may make as many moves with any number of ships as he wishes, up to the total value of the two dice, but not to exceed the value of one of the dice in the movement of any, single ship. Unit types are troopers, fighters, transports, and mines. Fighters automatically eliminate troop ships; fighter vs. fighter is determined by high roller. Troops are carried by troopships, and may be dropped on planets; combat on planets is resolved as with fighters.

Two sheets combine to form a 22"x16" mapboard. 121 thin counters are perforated for separation. Two dice are also included. A limited set of advanced rules are also provided.

28590.name: Game of State Capitals
28590.description:
Discs, each of which names one of the forty-eight state capitals, are dealt to the players. In turn, a spinner which indicates two of the states by number (the order in which they were added to the union, really) is spun. If the player has the state capital discs matching those states, the player must declare that fact to surrender the discs. Sometimes the spinner allows a player to surrender two discs.

Alaska and Hawaii were added to the game when those states entered the union.

The first player to place all one's state capitals in their proper places on the gameboard wins.

28591.name: The Spirit of '76
28591.description:
Brigade/Regiment-level simulation of the American Revolutionary War, specifically the Southern Campaign conducted between 1778 and 1782. The four-sheet, 22"x16" strategic map is centered on the Carolinas, with portions of Virginia and Georgia also represented. Approximately 250, half-inch counters represent the forces available.

Movement of forces is by pre-plotted orders, with opposing forces ending the week in the same hex having their combat resolved on a separate set of geomorphic, tactical combat boards.

The tactical combat system is rather advanced for the time, including such elements as LOS, panic, bayonet attacks, enfilade fire, cavalry charges, facing, and elevation advantages. The strategic game also has rules for supply/foraging, lines of communication, weather, forced march, baggage trains, partisans, forts and garrisons.

28592.name: Off the Hook
28592.description:
Off The Hook is a fun-filled, action-packed poker game that combines calculated chance with thought-provoking strategy.

Each player gets ten white chips, two colored dice, one green marker, and one blue marker. The starting player takes five "community" dice, and one green die in the closed Off the Hook box. The player then shakes the box, and opens it to look inside, and announce a poker hand based on what they see. The box is then passed to the next player, who can either call their bluff, accept the call by looking in the box an making a new (higher) call, or give up an "Off the Hook" marker to pass the box without penalty.

If a player gets caught bluffing, they lose the number of chips to the challenger equal to the number showing on the green die in the box. Otherwise, the challenger pays.

The person with the most chips wins (usually the last one left in the game).

Home Page: http://www.offthehookpoker.com/

28593.name: Go Finish
28593.description:
This Western Australian production could possibly be described as parallel games of Scrabble without a board. Players each have a collection of lettered tiles and they create their own set of words that interconnect in the style of a crossword. Like Scrabble, each letter has a score with letters that are harder to use having a higher score.

Manufactured in Western Australia by Herbert Stone Pty Ltd, Trademark Registed Pending Taree Pty Ltd. Judging by the seven-digit phone numbers it is pre-1997.

28594.name: Silver Hawks
28594.description: Silver Hawks is a simple war type game that has players attempting to stop the Evil Mon'Star. The game makes use of spinners in order to determine if targets have been hit. Game comes with 6 cardboard characters and 2 spinners.

28595.description:
This is a REAL Dennis the Menace game. It has all the naughty, silly fun of Dennis in 'The Beano' and it is easy to learn as well. Each player must play three dirty tricks on characters on the board using various items they collect on their travels. (What could you do with a banana, a bucket, a rope and six pints of rasher slop ? ! )

BUT ... look out for Sergeant Slipper, if he catches you in the act it's curtains !

This is THE Dennis game. Just for kids or the whole family, it is brilliant fun. When Dad & Mum turn into children you know you have a good game on the table !
28595.name: Dennis the Menace and Gnasher

28596.name: GridIron Master
28596.description:
GridIron Master is a new strategy football-based board game. The game combines the strategic elements of football with the disciplines and patterns of chess.

The game play takes place on a wooden 'exact-to-scale' football field.

Both American football or Canadian football versions are available. The size of the field and rules differ depending on the version.

Player pieces are plastic pegs are shaped like football helmets. The football snaps on top of the pieces. Each football position is mapped to a corresponding chess position and the piece is allowed to maneuver accordingly.

Each football play is conducted as a miniature chess game, seamlessly integrating the strategies of both activities.

The "kicking game" is conducted by rolling the "football shaped" dice. The yardage or turnout is given by a look-up sheet which was compiled from years of actual football statistical information.

Become the King of Quarterbacks!

28597.name: Skance
28597.description:
(Publisher's description)
There are two challenging games to play on the SKANCE board. Both are easy to learn and fast to play.
In game one "Vanquish", the winner is the player who successfully removes all other players pieces from the board. However, a sharp eye is needed as there are four different ways to remove a player from the game. Luck is of course important... but so is your skill and strategy.
Game two is "Thwart" and the winner is the player who manages to occupy an opponent's home base with just one of his pieces. Sounds easy doesn't it? Wait until you try !

28598.name: Ma non i coperchi
28598.description:
A Italian party games introduced from a famous showman of TV.
Better if played with many people.

28599.name: Gioca con me al Campionato di Formula 1
28599.description: An old Italian racing game of F1. Move is spinner based. There is a plastic sheet where summarize, with counters, for every cars, laps, tire type, box stop etc.

28600.name: Kampen om Borås (Kunskapsspelet)
28600.description:
Kampen om Borås (Kunskapsspelet) is a game about the Swedish city of Borås. The mechanics is, roughly, a mix of Monopoly and Trivial Pursuit where most of the questions are about the city and its history.

Home Page: http://www.kunskapsspelet.se

28601.name: Football Game
28601.description: Play on any flat surface, set out the flags & goals to represent a football pitch. Set out the players (counters) in any formation you wish & move the ball around by flicking. Place the white disc ( the ball) in the center & toss a coin to decide who kicks off.

28602.description: The Super Deluxe Map: Napoleonic Wars expands the size of the original map, making the game even more playable. This map also adds several charts that were only available on separate play aids in the original game. When published by GMT, the map came packaged with version 1.2 of the rules.
28602.name: Napoleonic Wars: Super Deluxe Map

28603.name: Hard Burn
28603.description:
A "Firefly"-themed card game similar to Mille Bornes. Make money, but keep flyin'.
From the rulebook:
"Well, you’ve just pulled of a heist of valuable medications from St. Lucy’s Hospital in Ariel City on the planet Ariel. All you need to do is fly out to the border planets and sell them. However, the Hands of Blue are in pursuit! In order to escape them, you must fly through the Black and avoid all the hazards that will slow you down and get you pinched by them. If you fly far enough in the ‘Verse, you should be safe to sell off your stolen cargo. They won’t fly 86 million miles for a box of band-aids, will they?
In this game you try to fly 86 million miles through space to escape the Hands of Blue. But you must be wary, because your competition is doing the same and will tip off your enemies to your location (by playing cards to stop or slow you down), of course, you can do the same!
In the basic game, designed for 4 players, the object is to be the first crew to accumulate $5000 in platinum (that is the point system) over several rounds of play. In doing so, you must try to complete a trip of exactly 86 million miles in each round of play."

28604.description:
Rise Again: Honest Brawls Between Folk

Firefly-themed card based fighting game somewhat based on Kung Fu Fighting.
From the designer:
"You can’t take the sky from me: In RISE AGAIN, 2 to 6 players fight each other Firefly ‘Verse style, trying to beat the gos se (which we politely call “GUTS”) out of one another with various forms of brawlin’. Players can attack each other with Attack cards or by using a Weapon card they have in play. Players can make their attacks even more hi-larious by playing Attack Enhancement cards and by having a Stereotype card in play. Defenders use Block cards to avoid or cancel attacks, and can even play Guts Restoration cards to restore lost Guts."
28604.name: Rise Again: Honest Brawls Between Folk

28605.name: Black Hole Invaders
28605.description:
The object of the game is to get your space plane back to the Mothership first, or have 3 Mothership cards, but beware to the black Hole Invaders. If you end up with 3 Invader cards you are captured and out of the game.

A limited print run sci-fi game by Omega games.

28606.name: Firefly Card Game
28606.description:
Play events and actions on each other while trying to do the job, get paid. First one to amass 1000 credits, wins.

Home Page: http://wydraz.110mb.com/firefly/ffcg.htm

28607.description: A pond is filled with different types of fish. Dice rolls determine which type of fish is caught. Winner is the one who catches the most fish.
28607.name: Fische fangen

28608.name: Gunfight at Tombstone (Legends of the Far West)
28608.description:
"Gunfight at Tombstone" uses 8 high quality, huge miniatures (54 mm) to recreate the famous wild west shooting, so its high cost.

Each player controls one side (lawmen or outlaw in an 8 player game) with four cowboys each.
Each gunmen has his own and unique stats (drawing, movement, health, and hidden dice=shooting skill) and special abilities (re-rolls, cancel other abilities, improved shooting ranges...). The game uses some of the liars dice poker mechanics, you have to make the best hand possible to win your opponent and to pass a minimum hand depending on distance and covers, otherwise the shoot is lost. Unlike poker you don´t bet money but the bullets of your revolver or rifle. Depending on the bullets bet you make more or less damage. Movement and covers, ranges, team play, wise special ability using, and bullet administration-reload are crucial tactics to win the game.

A fast game and very easy to learn if you can play poker. A very original and unusual playable diorama.

28609.description: In the new version, the winner is not the person with the most money, but the one who earns the most "life points" — a mix of wealth and life experiences, he says. Instead of cash, each player holds a colored Visa card. They're the size of real cards, but numbers and letters are printed, not embossed. Cards aren't swiped, but placed in an electronic device that stores player data. Players can go into debt on the card.
28609.name: The Game of Life: Twists & Turns
boardgamepodcastepisode: Cubepushers - Episode 2: Traitors Everywhere!
Episode 25 – Parker Spiele – Neuheiten Frühjahr 2007

28610.name: Dirty Dicing
28610.description:
In Dirty Dicing, players roll six standard dice and use the results to fill in boxes on a scoresheet. Players also get two "smart moves" which they can use to pass a bad roll to the next player or to refuse dice which have been passed to them. Doubles are ignored, so a roll with three doubles scores nothing and is known as "dirty dice".

Dirty Dicing was published in Counter Magazine #36.

28611.name: Cranium Squawkbox: Pirate's Passage
28611.description: Square cards are used to create a layout of paths through a square "ocean" with the box (which is also the goal square of the game) at the center. The players' home islands/ starting squares are at the corners. The game's box is a molded plastic affair containing a voice chip; in turn, players push a button on top to hear a pirate voice give commands such as Rotate a card, Flip a card, Sail the Seas (move one space if you can), etc. First player to reach the treasure with his or her ship pawn is the winner.

28612.name: In the Name of Glory (fifth edition)
28612.description:
In The Name Of Glory (ITNOG) is a grand tactical rules set designed for players seeking a game of moderate complexity. The basic unit is a brigade, comprised of four stands. It uses a card activation system, with a few twists (see below). But players always has fewer cards than units (ain’t that always the way?). The game focuses more on morale than raw strength, and in fact units and combat effects are measured in morale points, rather than strength points. While units pretty much obey the player’s wishes, the card system makes for a very dynamic and unpredictable turn sequence.

List Of Ingredients

ITNOG comes as a 94 page book with a spiral binding and two player aid cards on card stock (despite what the back cover says, these are not laminated). There is a dash of color on the inside, with small pictures of beautifully painted 28 mm figures through out. The rules run 56 pages, followed by seven of optional rules. Also included are:

Counters to be copied onto card stock and cut out.
A chronology of the Revolutionary and Napoleonic Wars
A list of the battles between 1792 and 1815
Army Lists with commander ratings
A small scenario the Battle of Arroyo de Molinos.
Players will need to make a variety of counters or markers to play the game, or else develop paper rosters if they prefer.

28613.description:
Like the original Take Your Pick, this is a party game where one player is the subject and everyone else draws three cards, each of which has two choices on it A or B. The judges orient their cards in their hands such that they select one option from each card (turn the card one way, and the top word is circled, rotate it 180 degrees and the other word is circled).

In turn, each judge calls out the two words on one of his cards to the subject, who answers his preference. If the judge was correct, he keeps the card and continues. Wrong, and his turn ends. The subject gets the same score as the judge who got the most points this turn.

Quick and entertaining, which is what SimplyFun party games seem to be.

This edition includes entertainment choices (Batman or Spiderman, P Diddy or Led Zeppelin, etc).
28613.name: Take Your Pick: Movies, Music, & More

28614.name: Hip Flip
28614.description: This very unusual game had a stick with hands on both ends. Two dancers would stand on either side so that each person was being held by a hand. In between the hands was a spinable hanging plastic piece. The object of the game was to have the dancers gyrate in such a way that that center piece spun around. Whichever team that could keep the spinner rotating the longest was declared the winner.

28616.name: Head to Head Sudoku Game
28616.description:
From the Manufacturer: Battle against a friend with Cardinal's Head To Head Sudoku Game. Choose from three levels of difficulty and compete against the clock to see who comes out on top.
Game includes:
-100 puzzles & solutions
-2 game boards
-162 number tiles
-Timer
-Head to head divider

28618.name: Hokie Football
28618.description:
The object of Hokie Football is to score more points than your opponents while getting rid of all cards in your hand. Cards represent the yard lines on an American football field, and players can score points by playing touchdowns and getting rid of cards. Each hand ends when one player is out of cards.

Players start at mid field and move towards the end zones by playing one card per turn. If a player cannot play a card from their hand, they put points in a pot, and the person who goes out of cards at the end of the round gets all of the points in the pot. Playing touchdown cards scores for the player.

The player with the most points after multiple hands wins.

28619.description:
Pitch Bowl is a small print (400) game, self-published by a French designer. Rules are in English and French.

The game use the mechanics of the finger pitch to simulate a American Football game.
Each player directs wood tokens that represent Runner or Quarterback and different rules simulate Interceptions, Passes, etc.

The goal is to score 3 touchdowns.
28619.name: Pitch Bowl

28620.description:
Empires rise and fall. In the buffer areas and crossroads between civilizations, however, a clever ruler can sometimes adopt new ideas, establish trade, and found a city state -- such as the great Phoenician cities of Tyre and Sidon -- that will outlast many neighbouring empires. Phoenicia is about building an empire worthy of an entry into the annals of time. You must build up your economy and increase your population whilst holding all others at bay. You will be challenged by your neighbouring countries to the next technology advancement that will help you to feed your population.

Some of this game's mechanics were inspired by Outpost.
28620.name: Phoenicia
boardgamepodcastepisode: The Game Pit: Episode 44 - Lobstercon

28621.description:
From the publisher's site:

The first in a series of detailed handbooks for ATS players filled with illustrated examples of play and instruction articles. Each issue is about 40 pages.

The first issue of ATS WARFIGHTING GUIDE #1 also includes a bonus multi-turreted tank play aid for owners of ADVANCED TOBRUK + a free bonus GOODY..

Articles cover analysis of machine-gun and mortars in ATS, a look at Panther Tanks in the system, compared to US Army data, and a couple of new variants...plus we hear more from the Hal Hock correspondence collection...and more!
28621.name: ATS Warfighting Guide #1

28622.name: Enchanted Checkers
28622.description: Checkers variant. Meant to be played with miniatures. Each pawn has it's own special power. 36+ different powers available. Fantasy theme army lists included. Lots of Variants. Not your Grandpa's Checkers. Free homebrew ruleset available at: http://www.angelfire.com/games2/warpspawn/EC.html

28623.name: Rekkakuskit
28623.description:
In Rekkakuskit (the truck drivers) each player tries to make their living by running a transportation company. They get paid for delivering consignments but must cover their expenses. The winner is the player that has gained most capital at the end of the game.

In the beginning the players get the starting capital, the operation permit cards and place their pawns in Helsinki also taking the initial freight card. Each freight card shows a destination and a table of fees. The actual fee depends on the zone one's pawn is located and the type of the operation permit.

The game board is a map of Finland divided in three zones: southern, middle and northern Finland. The map shows the largest cities and a set of roads (tracks of squares) between them. There are two types of operation permits and you may buy an extended permit to operate with improved rates.

Moving your truck (pawn) happens by roll-and-move and should one land on a given square an event card is drawn. The major part of events consist of maintenance costs. Once the destination city is reached a new freight card is drawn.

28624.name: Roll-Ralli
28624.description: Each player is trying to acquire a ticket and go to the airport as fast as possible. The first player at the airport with a ticket is the winner.

28625.name: UCSD-opoly
boardgamepublisher: Late for the Sky Production Company
28625.description: This is a University of California at San Diego themed variant of Monopoly. Houses and Hotels are replaced by Years of Credit and Diplomas. There are no auctions, and all money required to be paid other than rent and the purchase price of properties is placed in the center of the board. Any player landing on Spring Break (Free Parking) collects all of the money from the center of the board. Playing pieces are History, Art, Anatomy, English, and Calculus textbooks. Unique properties include the Quonset Huts, the Price Center, the Guardian, the Sun God, the Koala, Revelle Plaza Fountain, the Hump, Genesee Avenue, Che' Cafe, Canyon View Pool, Muir College, Warren College, Fifth College, Revelle College, and Thurgood Marshall College.

28626.description:
In a lonely outpost, on the border between the Roman Empire and the barbarian hinterlands stands a small group of Roman soldiers. Raids by barbarian hordes threaten your Legion, and soon the Empire itself! Someone is growing rich from these raids and it may not be the barbarians alone. As the Twentieth Legion teeters on the brink of collapse, YOU must find a way to stop the Wolves on the Rhine!

Wolves on the Rhine is a complete historical fiction adventure for solitaire or group play. This game includes the adventure booklet, game rules, playing pieces and game board. It is suitable for ages 12 and up and can be played with either the included Legends of the Ancient World games system or other game systems such as Melee.

Home Page: http://www.darkcitygames.com/display.php?series=law&;id=10
28626.name: Legends of the Ancient World: Wolves on the Rhine

28627.description:
Rules for English Civil War wargames with army lists and campaign system.

This set of rules was developed from the author's house rules, originally designed for the War of Spanish Succession, and subsequently adapted for a wide variety of periods.

28628.description:
Mare Nostrum is a expansion for Amirauté. It contains tactical and strategic scenarios for the Mediterranean war in 1940-1943, and new rules. It contains also ship cards for French, Italian, and British navies.

Expands:

Amirauté
28628.name: Mare Nostrum

28629.name: Forlorn Hope
28629.description: Miniatures wargames rules for the English Civil War. Recently revised and expanded by Partizan Press. Contains army lists for King, Parliament and the Covenant forces plus Catholic and Protestant Irish; color plates depicting numerous flags from all of the factions, with particular attention to the London Trained Bands and 4 introductory scenarios, in colour, explore the many varied engagements of the period (Tadcaster 1642, Corbridge 1644, Dunbar 1650, Wigan Lane 1651).

28630.name: Black Pawn Trucking
28630.description:
As the owner of a small freight operation, you must travel around the U.K carrying raw goods and finished products to their destinations.

This is a solitaire game for the piecepack system where the aim is to stay solvent for one game year, and if possible make a profit. Plan your routes and where to bring each good carefully, and don't take too many loans, or it could mean the end of your business.

28631.name: Happily Ever After Card Game
28631.description:
Help Ariel kiss her Prince before sunset so she can become human and live happily ever after.

Collect one Ariel, one Prince Eric, one Kiss, and one Princess Ariel card of the same color to win! Be the first Princess to help Ariel live happily ever after!

Ages 4 and up

28632.name: Memorise
28632.description:
To score points by memorizing details from and answering questions about a passage of text.

Players, either individually or in teams are invited into the world of some of the greatest storytellers ever. Short extracts from famous and classic novels take you into their world of thrills, chills, comedy and romance - but can you memorize what you have read?

If you can, and can answer your questions correctly, you'll score points. From simple "either/or" questions to real tests of memory and recall. Memorise is an exciting and tense battle of wit and nerve. Tactics and strategy may allow you to secure valuable bonus points.

This game is simple to learn and, unlike most question and answer games, requires no previous knowledge. All the answers are in the passage that you have just read - but can you memorise them?.

This game also gives you a flavor of the contents of a number of famous and classic novels.

Note: Memorise appears to be a reprint of Echelon. The text and question cards are exactly the same, but a cheaper board and playing pieces have been substituted.

28633.name: Maxwell: The Game
28633.description:
A rather tongue-in-cheek game of amusement at the expense of Robert Maxwell!

The purpose is to become a tycoon and then become the administrator for the pension fund!

The aim is to land on the Maxwell Squares and collect the 5 different items that enable you to become a tycoon: Newspaper Owner, Yacht owner, Football Club director, Cigar smoker, and finally Pension Fund Administrator.

To win the game, you must have collected all 5 cards, and then be the first person to the pension fund. To do this you must first accept that you have died!!! You must then move along the 3 sets of coins before entering your kingdom of untold riches. The first to the riches wins.

28634.name: Matchday
28634.description: As Team Manager, the player's goal is to lead his football (soccer) team to win the League Championship during the course of one season's play. Game uses some ideas from Monopoly, but also features the matches, injuries, transfers, gate attendance, and other aspects of being a football manager.

28635.name: Match and Move
28635.description: Each player must try to move his four pieces across the board to the opposite side. The winner is the first player to do so. There is no "taking" or removing shapes from the board, and there must never be more than one piece on any square. Players have to match shape or color to move.

28636.name: Marenko: The Phrase Game
28636.description:
To accumulate the highest amount of Marenko Points by composing meaningful and correct sentences with the available cards.

520 special cards to compose sentences, together with 72 x sold vinyl "chips". Everybody rewards you whenever you form a good sentence. You also get rewards any time you expand somebody else's phrase.

28637.name: Maindealer
28637.description:
A very unusual and interesting adaptation of real life car sales/trading translated into a boardgame.

You start play as a normal everyday person, a "punter", whose compelling ambition is to become a car dealer. Through life's ups and downs, you must collect the 5 cars you need, of any make, to become a garage owner.

Once a garage owner, you move to the next level on the board, with the opportunity to buy & sell additional cars, and also to aim for a main dealership - if you have sufficient stock of one make of car.

A very clever and absorbing game- easy to pick up as you go.

28638.name: Monopoly: German
28638.description:
Released in the 1930's in Germany by licensee Firma Franz Schmidt.

Gameplay is the same as the original Monopoly. The Currency is the German deutschmark.

The release is notable for having a board that folds into quarters, rather than halves.

- Go is Los
- Chance and Community Chest are Ereignis-fach and Gemeinschafts-fach, respectively
- Trafalgar Square is Opernplatz
- Boardwalk is SchloBallee

28639.name: Château: Vinspelet
28639.description:
Each player starts the game in charge of a small wine trading company with contacts to wineries in three different countries. Your company is represented on the board by a wine merchant and a buyer. These pawns move around the board in hope of buying fine wines and their requisite grapes. A wine and grape combination together form an agency.
The game ends when one player has at least six agencies representing at least five different countries. But the winner is the one with the most successful company, i.e. the highest monetary value of combined resources.

28640.name: Pop-Cones
28640.description: This is like a junior version of "Trouble" and features Kohner's trademark Pop-O-Matic. Tokens are cones as you'd see in Kohner's "Headache" game. Same object as any of those go-around-the-board-to-Home games.

28641.name: Photo-opoly
boardgamepublisher: Late for the Sky Production Company
boardgameversion: Late for the Sky Production Company edition
28641.description:
from the publishers:

No one takes a picture of something they want to forget! Make a game that is unforgettable! Where are your photos anyway? Photo albums? Stored on the memory card of your digital camera? Stuffed in shoe boxes under the bed?

CALLING ALL PHOTOS! COME OUT AND PLAY! Choose 22 favorite photos and create a game for: A BIRTHDAY, A FAMILY REUNION, A WEDDING, A PARTY, A BABY SHOWER, AN ANNIVERSARY, ANY CELEBRATION, ANY EVENT. You don’t even really need an occasion!

Maybe you’ve just always wanted to make your own game! Materials and instructions included for creating your game in many different ways.

28642.name: Fishin'-opoly
boardgamepublisher: Late for the Sky Production Company
boardgameversion: Late for the Sky Production Company edition
28642.description:
from the publishers:

THE GAME THAT WILL REEL YOU IN, HOOK, LINE AND SINKER!
Gone Fishin’ – when grouped together, two of the most beautiful words in the English language! Fishin’-opoly allows players to buy, sell and trade their favorite fish and gear with family and friends. Players choose their tokens and advance to Cast. It’s all fun and games until someone lands on SNAG, gets all hung up, and is out of the game for three turns! While playing, flip over the deeds and learn some fun fishin’ facts. And you know what they say, “A bad day of fishin’ is still better than a good day at work!”

28643.name: Farm-opoly
boardgamepublisher: Late for the Sky Production Company
boardgameversion: Late for the Sky Production Company edition
28643.description:
from the publishers:

Here's a property tradin' game for farmers or those who just think farmin' is cool! It's life down on the farm where players increase their profit by collecting Acres and trading them in for Big Red Barns. Full of country humor and fun farm facts, Farm-opoly is a celebration of an All-American way of life!

28644.name: DIY-opoly
boardgamepublisher: Late for the Sky Production Company
boardgameversion: Late for the Sky Production Company edition
28644.description:
from the publishers:

A DO IT YOURSELF PROPERTY TRADING GAME!
Is your idea of high fashion a well-equipped tool belt?
Is your ideal vacation one in which you remodel the kitchen?
Do you spend your night out at the local hardware store?

If you answered yes to any or all of the above, D.I.Y.OPOLY is the game for you. Even you need a little R & R every now and then! Gather family and friends and welcome them into your world of power tools, elbow grease, and sawdust.

In D.I.Y.- OPOLY players buy, sell and trade favorite properties, then increase the property value by adding Tool Buckets and Hardware Stores. It sounds easy enough, but add a trip to the emergency room, a project you can’t handle, and an exploding toilet, and it gets a little more difficult, and a lot more fun! So choose your token and advance to “Get to Work!” Who knows? You may soon be elected Handyman of the Year…or you may get in over your head and have to hire a contractor. Whatever happens, it’s gonna be almost as fun as building a deck!

28645.name: Bookopoly
boardgamepublisher: Late for the Sky Production Company
boardgameversion: Late for the Sky Production Company edition
28645.description:
from the publishers:

OPEN A BOOK! THE WORLD AWAITS YOU!

Book-opoly allows players a glimpse inside the many worlds of classic literature. It’s a traditional property trading game where players buy, sell and trade their way to fun with family and friends. Interesting facts about the books and the authors are printed on the back of each property deed. Roll the dice and advance to Read. Collect Bookstores and trade them in for Libraries. Who knows! You may soon be elected President of the Book Club…or you may be tossed out of the game for three turns and sent to WATCH TV!

28646.name: Rodeo-opoly
boardgamepublisher: Late for the Sky Production Company
boardgameversion: Late for the Sky Production Company edition
28646.description:
from the publishers:

Giddy up Cowboys and Cowgirls! Here’s a game celebratin’ the rodeo! Whether you enjoy rodeo from the back of a bull, the saddle of a bronc, or viewed on the wide screen in the comfort of your easy chair, you’ll have a whole mess a’ fun playin’ Rodeo-opoly with family and friends! Full of rodeo humor and rodeo facts, Rodeo-opoly is a big “Hats Off” to this fascinatin’ sport and way of life. Buy favorite rodeo properties. Increase rent on your properties by collecting Scores and trading them in for Gold Buckles. It’s all fun and games until you’re sent to Bucked Off, then you’re skiddin’ on your back side across the board and you’re out for three turns!

28647.name: Maatilapeli
28647.description:
Players are part-time farmers in Maatilapeli. Each player owns a small farm with some arable land and forest. It is possible to grow wheat, potatoes, sugar beets and strawberries. Players buy seeds, sow and harvest them and sell the crop paying also taxes. The most successful farmer in terms of capital wins.

A round of the square game board represents one year, each side roughly representing one season: in winter players decide which seeds to buy and to what extent, in spring the seeds are sown, in summer (and partly autumn) it is the harvest time.

Advancing on the board happens by rolling a die. Each square represents one week and has special instructions on it: paying random expenses, drawing a surprise card, getting income out of the forest etc.

The harvest times of different plants are sequential and differ in length. The die roll the player lands on one of the harvest squares of certain plant also determines the hectare price of that crop (lookup table used). It is possible to miss the harvest season of any plant resulting in a crop failure for which the state pays a small compensation.

Harvesting machinery may be bought to increase the crop price and a tractor decreases the sowing expenses. More land can be rented or bought as well. At the end of the year the taxes are paid, the accounts balanced and a new year may begin.

The game includes two sets of rules: in the simplified set e.g. everyone grows one hectare of each plant, there is no machinery or, obviously, no option to rent or buy more land.

28649.name: Bug-opoly
boardgamepublisher: Late for the Sky Production Company
boardgameversion: Late for the Sky Production Company edition
28649.description:
from the publishers:

A CREEPING, CRAWLING, PROPERTY TRADING GAME!

Bug-opoly is a look inside the wonderful bug kingdom. Buy, sell and trade your favorite insects (and a few of their friends because not every bug included in the game is technically an insect.) As you play, flip over the deeds and read some amazing and fun facts. Gather family and friends and get buggy with it! Who knows? You may soon be elected president of the Entomological Society…or you may be sent to Bug Off, and out of the game for three turns! Whatever happens, the game will be crawling with good fun!

28650.name: The Transformers Game
28650.description:
The Transformers Game
2-4 Players
Ages 6 and up

Feel the tension build as opposing forces converge. The more battles you win, the greater your chances of taking over Command Headquarters to win the game.

Contents:
Gameboard
40 Cards
12 "Transformers" in four colors
1 die

Object of the game:
To gain control of Command Headquarters by getting all your Transformers there first in robot form.

Players roll a die and choose which of their three Transformers to move.

If they land on the same space as another player then they battle. Cards are played simultaneously, with the highest card winning. It takes two victories to win a battle. When a battle is won the winner Transforms to a robot and the loser Transforms to an airplane.

Cards may be discarded and new ones redrawn on the white star burst "power spaces". The blue arrow spaces allow the player to use the short cut.

The first player to move all three of their pieces (in robot form) into the Command Headquarters wins.

28651.name: Splurge
28651.description: Splurge is an exciting game of skill and fortune for 2 to 6 players. It incorporates in a single board game a number of famous and popular dice and card games (poker, blackjack, craps, etc...). Each player attempts to win by a combination of plays on the board and successful side-betting with other players in the game. The game is ended when one player gets both his tokens to the finish, and the winner is the player who has accumulated the most money at that time.

28652.name: Task Force 421 (Iran-Iraq naval war, 1980)
28652.description:
Task Force 421 is an attempted simulation of the most important combined naval and air battle of the Iran-Iraq War 1980-1988, named Operation Morvarid (pearl), in a tactical/operational level. This particular battle took place in two days, during 27 and 28 November 1980; initiated by Iran landing a small Special Forces demolition team aboard the Iraqi al-Bakr offshore platform. Al-Bakr was a significant intelligence gathering post, and a safe haven for the Iraqi missile boats, from which to operate against the Iranian shipping. Before the start of the war, over one-third of the Iraq’s oil was exported via al-Bakr and the nearby al-Omayeh platform.

The main map illustrates the northern Persian Gulf and parts of the Iranian, Iraqi and Kuwaiti coasts, divided into flat-up hexes, each representing a distance of 4.5 kilometers across.

A unit is an individual naval vessel or aircraft. The counters represent the Iranian and Iraqi naval and air forces, distinguishable by color, and their national flags. The Iraqi counters have beige background, while the Iranian counters have grey background.

28653.description: Dien Bien Phu: Trenches in the Tropics is a simple simulation of the battle of Dien Bien Phu (March 13 – May 7 1954). This decisive battle saw French elite troops (paratroopers of Bigeard and the Légion étrangère) defeated by the Vietminh led by General Vo Nguyen Giap. It put an end to the French domination over Indochina and was a great victory for the Vietnamese Communist party who would be seen, after this event, as the party who gave freedom to its own people. Dien Bien Phu: Trenches in the Tropics is a two-player war game. One player commands the Vietminh, while the other commands the French forces.
28653.name: Dien Bien Phu: Trenches in the Tropics

28654.name: Say Cheese
28654.description:
Grab the entire card deck, Say Cheese and win!

Based on the War card game. Your goal is take all the cheese cards by drawing higher numbered cards than your opponent. In the event of tie, extra cards are drawn and compared to determine who wins the playoff. But keep an eye out for the cat and mouse trap cards as they can help you get additional bonus cards.

28655.name: Juneau-Opoly
28655.description: Juneau-Opoly was designed in 2006 as a fund-raising board game for the Juneau Douglas High School Band Program. It is played much like Monopoly in that players roll dice to advance around the board and purchase properties. Properties are named after Juneau, AK businesses and once a player acquires all the businesses in a set he/she may purchase customers to make the business collect more when other players land on them. There are also fate and foxfire spaces that force the player to draw a random event card when landed on. These cards have a variety of effects, such as giving or taking away money. The game is won when a player manages to bankrupt everyone else. A player becomes bankrupt when he lands on an owned property that he/she can't pay the owner for.

28656.name: Operation Husky (1943)
28656.description:
“OPERATION HUSKY” (10 July – 17 August 1943)

American, British and Canadian troops land in the South of the Island. Their aim is to reach Messina, as the final plan is to liberate Italy from the German occupation. It is likely that the Axis would begin to evacuate forces from the island in the very near future, and it is vitally important that they are destroyed or captured before they can leave Sicily. This ensures that any subsequent invasion of the Italian mainland would be faced by far fewer Axis troops.
The most immediate objectives are airfields and ports in the advance towards Messina.
Depending on his reinforcement schedule, the Axis player may attempt to delay Allies conquest of the island, or decisively defeat the Allies by a strong counterattack.

Game Components:
- Map Board
- Sheet of Counters
- Rules Handout
- One 6 sided die

28657.description:
Japanese Submarine Offensive in the Eastern Solomons September 1942.

Sensuikan is a simple strategic simulation of the attempt of the Japanese Sixth Submarine Fleet to prey the U.S. carrier groups engaged, during the opening days of September 1942, in covering important convoys carrying reinforcements and supplies to Guadalcanal.

Sensuikan is a solitaire game in which a single Player controls both the opposing forces. The Player will command the Japanese submarine force by playing the role of Vice Adm. Komatsu Teruhisa , who, between August and September 1942, prepared and ordered the I-boats offensive from his headquarters in Truk. By contrast, the Allied escort groups will operate in accordance with a strictly defined set of rules. The specific game scenario will allow the Player to simulate the crucial moments which led on 15th September to sink the carrier U.S.S. Wasp and to hit some units of another carrier group built around the U.S.S. Hornet. As a consequence, the Player will be able to understand the logic of a submarine force whose potential was underestimated even by the High Japanese Command, and perceive the tension of Japanese sub-commanders in their ultimate search for high estimated preys, personal glory and, most of all, respect.
Specific rules for random events, like intelligence resources or air raids, will add to the realism of the game. Concurrently, these elements will also offer the opportunity to examine through a different perspective, limits and contradictions to the Imperial Japanese Navy management of its ‘silent service’ during one of the most intense (and largely unknown) phases of submarine warfare of the entire War in the Pacific.
28657.name: Sensuikan: Eastern Solomons Sept 1942

28658.name: The First Battle of Alamein: July 1st to 27th 1942
28658.description:
When speaking of ‘The battle of Alamein’ it is generally assumed that one is referring to the battle which finally saw Britain’s Eighth Army defeat Rommel’s much vaunted Panzerarmee Afrika in October/November 1942. However this was, in fact, the third battle fought at the Alamein position over a period of five months. The second battle, sometimes referred to as the ‘Battle of Alam Halfa’ or ‘Rommel’s last dash’, is seen as a necessary holding action which blunted the offensive capability of the Axis forces. The ‘First Battle of Alamein’ or ‘July Battles’ which concerns us presently has been given a comparatively negligent amount of historical attention; at times referenced as a hideously complex standstill or fatuously dismissed as insignificant. However, it was this battle which put a stop to Rommel’s gallop to Alexandria and began the change in Eighth Army’s fortunes that would eventually lead it to victory in November 1942.

The game map is a simple reproduction of the battle field of El Alamein in North Africa, from the Mediterranean Sea in the North to the impassable Qattara Depression in the South.

The Commonwealth player controls the units on the board which are Light Blue.
German Units are represented in Grey, and Italian units are represented in Green.

28659.name: Suomussalmi
28659.description:
Suomussalmi is probably the best known battle during the 1939-40 ‘Winter War’ between Finland and the USSR. It took place around the village of Suomussalmi and along the road leading to this village from the hamlet of Raate. The battle was fought between the 163rd and 44th divisions of the Red Army, the latter being a motorized division, against a composite Finnish division which was eventually called the 9th and had only a few artillery units and nothing else in support of its infantry battalions. The battle was fought from early December until early January and resulted in the complete destruction of the Soviet divisions.

The map covers the area around Suomussalmi and Haapavaara. It is divided into hexagons (hexes) each approximately 2.6 km across.
The counters for the two armies are slightly different in the information they contain as well as in the color. Soviet units are red and Finnish units grey. The unit size designations and arm-of-service designations are the standard NATO designations with two possible exceptions. Two lines at the top of the unit marks a battalion and three a regiment.

28660.name: Another Glorious First of June? Jutland 1916
28660.description:
THE BATTLE OF JUTLAND - 31ST MAY 1916

The aim of this game is to create a playable, but accurate strategic simulation of the Battle of Jutland. One of the most important aspects of war at sea is the difficulty of bringing an opponent to decisive battle, it took Nelson nearly two years to bring the French fleet to battle at Trafalgar, and in an era before radar or secure communication it remained as difficult. Therefore this simulation uses a double blind system to simulate these difficulties.

GAME CONTENTS

2 Search Charts – One British, One German
1 Turn Chart
100 Counters:
- 64 Ship Counters
- 4 Fleet Counters
- 16 Contact Counters
- 6 Light Cruiser Search Counters (2 Red, 4 Black)
- 3 Engadine Float Plane Searches
- 2 Radio Intercept Counters
- 2 Submarine Contact Counters
- 1 Zeppelin Search Counter
- 1 Turn Counter

28661.name: 1st Manassas: 21st July 1861
28661.description:
This game simulates the battle of 1st Manassas 21st July 1861 at brigade level in a series of 30 minute game. One player represents the forces of the United States, the other Confederate forces.
The map board represents an area 8 miles wide x 7 miles long. Each Hex is 300 yards in diameter.
Units are represented by double-sided hexagonal counters. The simulation is at brigade level, but a number of un-brigaded units are represented as are artillery batteries.

28662.name: DGA TV
28662.description:
from the publisher:

A co-operative game about running your own TV station.

We are Producers working together to bring Award Winning programming to the viewing public. We run 7 Studios, featuring everything from Children’s Shows to Current Affairs. We have to deal with the critics, ratings, sponsors and the actions of people behind and in front of the cameras.

With skill and luck we will avoid Cancellations and earn Awards.

This game has the flavor of casino games such as Blackjack. We try to put together as popular a TV program as we can, i.e., as high scoring a card hand of the best crew, top ratings and committed sponsors to counter the negative hand of mounting drops in ratings, loss of viewers and sponsors as well as some troubles among the station crew.

Expect lots of talk and debate. Clever teamwork and risk-taking are also needed or we will lose our shirts as the Cancellations pile up. Be careful, everything can quickly spin out of control. Good luck!

Includes: 8 game boards, rules, 6 movers, 7 success markers, 1 program marker, 41 thumbs up and 45 thumbs down cards, rules summary chart. © 2006

28663.name: Austerlitz, 2 December 1805
28663.description:
This simulation deals with the famous Battle of Austerlitz held in Moravia (Chech Republic today) during the 2nd of December 1805.
The simulation is designed with a full area map (provided) of the actual place, divided in hexagons. The dimensions represented are approximately 8miles from north to south and 8miles from east to west, thus every hex represents an area of 1/16 of a square mile, the actual dimension of every hex is around 400 meters from side to side.
The player controlling the French army gets 33 unit markers all in divisional, brigade or battalion level.
The player controlling the Allied army gets 30 unit markers all in divisional, brigade or battalion level.

28664.description:
This game is about the Veracruz Campaign during the Mexican-American War of 1845-1848.

The map is a 20x36 hexagon grid representing the operational area from Mexico City to the Gulf of Mexico and divided into three zones by red zone indicator lines. Each hex represents approximately 10km.
The Mexican forces are made up of primarily regulars of regimental size, but are augmented by Mexican cavalry, artillery, militia, guerrilla bands and local villagers capable of waging defensive combat. The US forces are composed of regimental sized infantry, artillery and engineers.
28664.name: 1847:  Road to Mexico City

28665.name: Dodge Bowl
28665.description:
Dodge Bowl is a novel dexterity game from Nash Games. In this you set-up 5 'bowling' pins on your side of the board and 3 blocking cubes in the center of the board.
The object is to knock down your opponents pins first. This is done by rolling a marble through a curved tube from your side of the board. The rules are simple and the game is a fun way to pass the time.

28666.name: Globe Trotting
28666.description: Very similar to Twister but with an educational slant. A spinner is used and children must put left or right hand, or left or right foot on the continent or ocean specified. Last player standing is the winner.

28667.name: Personality Probe...?
28667.description:
It is a game designed for three or more players (special rules for two players) and the more the merrier.

There are topics for everyone: children, husbands & wives, general (for everyone), and master-mind (for the deep thinkers and serious minded.) It is a good way to communicate with each other and learn how to think about oneself and life using over a thousand provocative, unique, stimulating and sometimes humorous questions. Because these questions don't always come up in everyday conversations, it is a chance to gain insights about each other in a pleasant, relaxed, and enjoyable atmosphere.

28668.name: The Battle of the Nile
28668.description:
The Battle of the Nile - 1st and 2nd August, 1798
There are four different Scenarios that can be played, namely the Historical Scenario ( which simulates what actually happened in the Battle of the Nile ) and three other Scenarios called Scenario A, Scenario B and Scenario C.

The Board is a grid of flat up hexagonal zones, measuring 52 rows by 44 columns. The Board represents an area of approximately 2.5 miles by 1.9 miles at the North West part of Aboukir Bay.

Each counter represents one ship-of-the-line. There are 14 British ships and 13 French ships, each identified by their national flags and their names. Each ship counter spans two hexes.

28669.name: Westminster Abbey or Glorious Victory!
28669.description:
The Battle of Cape St Vincent,14th February 1797.
Each unit represents one ship of the line. None of the frigates or other ships present are represented, as they played no part in the battle.
There are 15 British ships and 27 Spanish ships, identified by their national flags.

28670.name: Whigs & Scalps
28670.description:
Whigs & Scalps is a two-player grand strategic conflict simulation of the French & Indian War. The map represents an area stretching from the Gulf of Mexico to Northern Québec and from the Mississippi Valley to the Atlantic. The period covered goes from 1755 to 1760, each game turn representing a full year of real time.
Historically, despite some initial French victories, the British and Americans managed to conquer Nouvelle-France and effectively end French presence in Northern America.

28671.name: Clash of Empires: Magnesia 190BC
28671.description:
A Conflict Simulation of the Battle of Magnesia in 190BC between the armies of the Roman Republic and the Seleucid Empire.
The Clash of Empires game contains
- the game-map
- the Roman and Seleucid army counters
- “Push Back” counters
- A six sided dice is also needed.
The counters are organized into seven Divisions (four Roman and three Seleucid).
